comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content: Morgan saved the gold standard in 1895 by convincing European bankers to buy US T-bonds. US reserves of gold had been sinking at the rate of $2 million a day and reached a low of $40 million at one point. By 1914 things were in pretty good shape but then war broke out and everyone went off the gold standard. The gold standard wasn't restored until 1925 and didn't last much longer after that. Today of course gold and silver are a distant memory and none of our coins are worth the zinc they're made of.

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content: on Lusitania's 3rd westbound voyage, Nov 3, 1907, she carried a record gold shipment of $12,361.150  (approx $250,000,000 today)  the largest gold shipment on a ship at that time, because of a sudden US Treasury demand. The shipment is described as gold bars, so it's interesting to see small barrels here.  It makes you wonder what form it has inside them.

comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content: These appear to be US dry half barrels (a full dry barrel is 28x17 inches). I found a couple references to shipping gold bars in dry barrels. A half barrel holds about 55 l, and the density of gold is around 19, so if you filled one of these it would weigh over 1000 Kg! I suspect they put a few bars in each barrel and the rest is empty space. A standard gold bar today is 400 troy ounces or 12 Kg and measures 7 x 3-5/8 x 1-3/4 inches.

comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content: On second thought these are too small even for half barrels.
